data.title: Film Openings and Film Series Listings
data.text:
Opening This Week

"BIKER BOYZ" — In the world of underground motorcycle racing clubs, one man (Laurence Fishburne) is the undisputed champ until a young upstart (Derek Luke) arrives to challenge him. Reggie Rock Bythewood directed, based on a New Times article by Michael Gougis; with Orlando Jones, Lisa Bonet, Larenz Tate, Djimon Hounsou and Kid Rock. (PG-13) Opens Fri.

"CHAOS" — In Coline Serreau's drama, a couple (Catherine Frot, Vincent Lindon) is sidetracked on their way to a party by the sight of a prostitute being beaten. Later the wife, consumed by guilt, goes to visit the injured woman (Rachida Brakni) in the hospital, where they strike up an unusual partnership. In French, with subtitles. (No rating) (1:48) Opens Wed.

"FINAL DESTINATION 2" — David R. Ellis's horror thriller sequel stars A. J. Cook, Ali Larter and Tony Todd in a tale about a young woman who has repeated premonitions that her friends are about to die so she races about trying to prevent her visions from coming true. (R) (1:37) Opens Fri.

"THE GURU" — A successful Indian dancer comes to New York seeking fame and fortune but winds up a waiter living in a Queens walkup. His fortunes change when he meets a socialite and is mistaken for a wise Hindu healer. Daisy von Scherler Mayer directed this comedy; with Heather Graham, Marisa Tomei, Jimi Mistry, Michael McKean and Christine Baranski. (R) (1:31) Opens Fri.

"THE LAST LETTER" — Frederick Wiseman's first fiction film is an adaptation of Vassili Grossman's play. Catherine Samie plays a mother who writes a letter to her son just before she is deported by the Nazis. In French, with subtitles. (No rating) (1:01) Shown with Yitzhak Goskind's 10-minute Yiddish-language documentary "JEWISH LIFE IN CRACOW," filmed in Poland in 1939. Film Forum, 209 W. Houston St., west of Sixth Ave. (212-727-8110) Opens Wed., through Feb. 11

"L'CHAYIM, COMRADE STALIN!" — In 1928 Stalin set aside an area of Siberia as the first Jewish "homeland" — eventually it attracted as many as 45,000 settlers from all over the world. Yale Strom directed this documentary about Stalin's desire to create the Jewish Autonomous Region. In English, Russian and Yiddish, with subtitles. (No rating) (1:33) Quad Cinema, 34 W. 13th St. (212-255-8800) Opens Fri.
